title: Bayer’s Essure female sterility implant is under fire
text:
Bayer’s Essure female sterility implant is under fire Use your key for the next article A young woman Pixabay/Freephoto 
Bayer is running into some serious problems with it's female sterility implant which is called Essure. International Business Times reported on Sept. 25, 2015, there have been heightened safety concerns about Bayer’s Essure female sterility implant. There have been thousands of complaints by women who have used the device. 
Women have been complaining about Essure since the device's approval in 2002. They say they have experienced debilitating stomach pain and severe bleeding. Many of the complaints have been filed with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration by women who received an implant to make themselves sterile. There has been growing concern among regulators and patient advocates about the safety of the product which is called Essure. An FDA panel has questioned the agency about how careful it was in reviewing safety data for the Essure device. 
There has been testimony from patients and experts who have shared stories of persistent abdominal discomfort, allergic reactions and messed up insertions. Essure was developed by a subsidiary of Bayer. The product is a small metallic coil which is placed in the fallopian tubes. The presence of the coil causes fibrous scar tissue to develop around it therefore creating a physical barrier to stop sperm from reaching eggs. This offers women a nonsurgical permanent form of birth control . 
CBS News reports experts have questioned the safety of the Essure birth control implant. This device has been around for thirteen years. It has come under increasing scrutiny due to complaints of chronic pain, bleeding and fatigue by women using it. The Essure implant which is from German manufacturer Bayer has been marketed to women as the only non-surgical option which they have for permanent birth control. Bayer is now being confronted with serious problems with Essure. Suggested Links
